text: "Best Pizza in Tokyo: 2 Restaurants That Might Surprise You!" is a must-watch for pizza lovers exploring the city. This video showcases two hidden gems that blend authentic Italian techniques with Japanese precision, creating pies that are crispy, flavorful, and unforgettable. Whether you're a local or a visitor, these spots prove Tokyo‚Äôs pizza scene is world-class. Don‚Äôt miss out on these delicious surprises! üçïüáØüáµ‚ú®

text:
The real problem is the price.
Tokyo has any kind of food you can imagine.
Unfortunately the prices are unimaginable...
The real challenge is to find good and affordable food in Tokyo...
Particularly pizza will be expensive anywhere in Japan, because most of the ingredients like cheese, tomatoes, flour, are all expensive.

author: @YTO2TYO

text:
Honestly, in my experience, in Japan Italian food is very bad 95% of the time (mostly due to the kind of mass produced cheese that they put in everything). Shockingly so considering how high their basic standards are all other kinds of food. By this 95% I'm talking places like Saizeriya and other family restaurants, and the pasta sides in otherwise respectable lunch places, and the carbonara/pizza/etc dishes at 7/11 or Lawson. And even many of the pizzerias in touristy places that look superficially legit.

But the 5% of the time when it's done by artisans that actually understand Italian food, like these ones, it's world class.
author: @teokorhonen2207

text: Asia is cosmopolitan and wealthy though.  There are also millions of Western expats that live there and 7 out of 10 of the most visited cities on earth are in Asia.  Best believe that there are numerous famous Italian and Italian American chefs with restaurants all over Asia, so you can definitely get excellent Italian food in Asia.  Nevermind, the highly technical and skilled Asian chefs that can recreate any cuisine well.
